Life Science.Q: What is the powerhouse of the cell?
Life Science.A: Mitochondria
DNA
A trait that helps an organism survive.
The process of producing energy using oxygen.

Building blocks of proteins.
An organism that makes its own food.
Single-celled microorganisms.

Different species living in the same area.

A community of living and non-living things.

Change in species over time.

Life Science.Q: What is a kingdom in biology?
Life Science.A: A major classification of organisms.
Cell division that produces sex cells.
The powerhouse of the cell.
A change in DNA sequence.
Survival of the fittest.
A nerve cell that transmits electrical signals.
The role an organism plays in its environment.
DNA and RNA, which store genetic information.
A living thing.
The movement of water across a membrane.
An organism that lives on or in a host.
The process by which plants make food using sunlight.
A group of the same species in an area.
An animal that hunts and eats other animals.
An organism that makes its own food, usually through photosynthesis.
A molecule needed for growth and repair in living organisms.
The process of converting food into energy.
A group of organisms that can reproduce and produce fertile offspring.
A close relationship between two species.
The classification of organisms into groups.
A group of similar cells working together.
A substance that stimulates immunity to a disease.
A fertilized egg cell.

Physical Science.A: The rate at which velocity changes over time.
The smallest unit of an element that retains its properties.
The ability of an object to float in a fluid.
A process where substances transform into new substances.
The process of gas turning into a liquid.
The transfer of heat through direct contact.
Heat transfer through the movement of fluids.
Mass per unit volume of a substance.
The flow of electric charge.
The range of all types of electromagnetic radiation.
The capacity to do work.
A push or pull acting on an object.
A force that opposes motion between two surfaces in contact.
A state of matter with no fixed shape or volume.
The force of attraction between two masses.
The transfer of thermal energy from one object to another.
A testable scientific explanation.
The tendency of an object to resist changes in its motion.
A material that resists the flow of electricity or heat.
A charged atom or molecule.
Energy due to motion.

Physical Science.Q: What is the Law of Conservation of Energy?
Physical Science.A: Energy cannot be created or destroyed, only transferred.
The distance light travels in one year.
The amount of matter in an object.
Anything that has mass and takes up space.
The temperature at which a solid turns into a liquid.
A combination of substances that retain their individual properties.
The product of an object's mass and velocity.
A neutral particle in an atom’s nucleus.
Energy released from nuclear reactions.
Voltage = Current × Resistance.
A chemical reaction involving the loss of electrons.
Stored energy due to position.
A solid that forms from a solution during a chemical reaction.
Force applied per unit area.
A positively charged particle in an atom’s nucleus.
The emission of energy as electromagnetic waves.
The bending of light as it passes through different media.
Opposition to the flow of electric current.
The ability of a substance to dissolve in another.
A state of matter with a fixed shape and volume.
A homogeneous mixture of two or more substances.
The distance traveled per unit of time.
A measure of the average kinetic energy of particles.
A force that pulls on a material.
The total kinetic energy of particles in a substance.
Speed with direction.
A liquid’s resistance to flow.
The electrical potential difference between two points.
A disturbance that transfers energy through matter or space.
Force = Mass x Acceleration

Accounting.A: A resource owned by a business with economic value.
An obligation a company owes to others.
The owner's claim on business assets after liabilities are deducted.
A financial statement showing assets, liabilities, and equity.
A financial report showing revenue, expenses, and profit or loss.
Income earned from business operations.
Costs incurred in running a business.
Revenue minus expenses.
The allocation of an asset's cost over its useful life.
Generally Accepted Accounting Principles, the standard framework for financial reporting.
International Financial Reporting Standards, used for global financial reporting.
A professional who examines financial statements for accuracy and compliance.
The branch of accounting focused on external reporting.
Accounting focused on internal decision-making.
Accounting related to tax laws and regulations.
Value-Added Tax, a tax on goods and services.
A tax imposed on earnings by individuals and businesses.
A form submitted to report income and calculate tax liability.
A portion of a company's profits paid to shareholders.
A person or entity that owns shares in a company.
A business structure that is legally separate from its owners.
A business owned and operated by one person.
A business owned by two or more people.

Accounting.Q: What is a cash flow statement?
Accounting.A: A financial report showing cash inflows and outflows.
Profits kept in the business instead of distributed as dividends.
Money a business owes to suppliers.
Money owed to a business by customers.
A complete record of a company's financial transactions.
A report that checks the equality of debits and credits.
An accounting system where each transaction affects two accounts.
A record of financial transactions used for verification.
Recording revenues and expenses when they are incurred, not when cash is exchanged.
Recording revenues and expenses when cash is received or paid.
The value of a business's reputation, customer relationships, and brand.
The raw materials, work-in-progress, and finished goods held by a business.
A measure of how easily assets can be converted into cash.
A company's ability to meet its long-term debts and obligations.
A metric used to analyze a company's financial health.

Accounting.Q: What is the ethics principle in accounting?
Accounting.A: Ensuring honesty, transparency, and integrity in financial reporting.
Intentional deception in financial reporting for personal gain.
A financial plan estimating income and expenses for a period.

Accounting.Q: What is cost of goods sold (COGS)?
Accounting.A: The direct costs of producing goods sold by a business.
Current assets minus current liabilities.
The level of sales where total revenue equals total costs.
A cost that does not change with production levels.
A cost that changes with production levels.
A negative balance in a bank account allowed by the bank.
The process of paying employees their salaries and wages.
Assets are resources owned by a business that provide future economic benefits.

Accounting.Q: What are examples of non-current assets?
Accounting.A: Land, Buildings, Vehicles, Equipment, Furniture & Fixtures.

Accounting.Q: What are examples of current assets?
Accounting.A: Cash, Accounts Receivable, Inventory, Prepaid Expenses.
Liabilities are debts and obligations a business owes to others.

Accounting.Q: What are examples of non-current liabilities?
Accounting.A: Mortgage Payable, Bonds Payable, Long-Term Loans.

Accounting.Q: What are examples of current liabilities?
Accounting.A: Accounts Payable, Bank Overdraft, Short-Term Loans, Unearned Revenue, Accrued Expenses.
Owners' Equity represents the owner's claim on the business assets after liabilities are deducted.

Accounting.Q: What are examples of Owners' Equity accounts?
Accounting.A: Capital, Retained Earnings, Drawings, Revenue.

Accounting.Q: What is the difference between assets and liabilities?
Accounting.A: Assets are what a company owns, while liabilities are what a company owes.
Assets = Owners' Equity + Liabilities.
Assets = Owners' Equity + Liabilities
Resources owned by a business.
Obligations and debts owed by a business.
The owner's claim on business assets after liabilities.
Every transaction affects at least two accounts, keeping debits equal to credits.

Accounting.Q: What are the types of accounts in accounting?
Accounting.A: Assets, Liabilities, Equity, Income, and Expenses.
A business owned and operated by one person.
A business owned by two or more people.

Accounting.Q: What is a private company (Pty Ltd)?
Accounting.A: A company with limited liability that is not publicly traded.
A company that sells shares to the public.
Shares where dividends are paid only if profits allow.
Shares that receive fixed dividends before ordinary shares.
A dividend paid before the financial year-end.
A dividend declared at year-end.
A financial statement showing revenue, expenses, and profit/loss.
A financial statement listing assets, liabilities, and equity.

Ahtaju ila musaadah - أحتاج إلى مساعدة
Hal tatakallam al-ingliziyyah? - هل تتكلم الإنجليزية؟
Ana bikhayr, shukran - أنا بخير، شكراً
Min ayna anta? - من أين أنت؟
Kam thaman hadha? - كم ثمن هذا؟
Hal tasata'a musa'adati? - هل تستطيع مساعدتي؟
Tusbih ala khayr - تصبح على خير
La atakallam al-arabiyya - لا أتكلم العربية
Hal tatakallam al-ingliziyya? - هل تتكلم الإنجليزية؟
